caption.body: Choreographer-in-residence Yuri Possokhovâ€™s twelfth repertory work for San Francisco Ballet, ğ˜šğ˜¸ğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜®ğ˜¦ğ˜³, takes its inspiration from John Cheeverâ€™s short story ğ˜›ğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜šğ˜¸ğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜®ğ˜¦ğ˜³, a surrealistic story of a man who â€œswims homeâ€ through his neighborsâ€™ pools, only to find his homeâ€”and his life thereâ€”gone. Possokhov takes this concept of a man â€œswimming homeâ€ and weaves together images, moments, and settings from author Jack Londonâ€™s Martin Eden (1909), J. D. Salingerâ€™s Catcher in the Rye (1951), Vladimir Nabokovâ€™s Lolita (1955), as well as artist Edward Hopperâ€™s painting Nighthawks (1942), and director Mike Nicholsâ€™ film The Graduate (1967). Scene changes happen with the aid of film sequences, which reflect Possokhovâ€™s love of moving images, while giving a nod to Hollywood, another American cultural icon.   In the balletâ€™s last movement, the Swimmer is multiplied by fifteen men. â€œItâ€™s him, all of them, Possokhov saysâ€”one manâ€™s emotions, magnified.â€ The men dance with the fluidity and weightlessness that come with immersion in water, yet there is ferocity too. â€œItâ€™s like a kind of confession,â€ he continues. The mad dance is a â€œlast song, last scream, last swim.â€ Then the men are washed away, leaving only the Swimmer onstage.   Special thank you to San Francisco Ballet for making this exhibition possible. See â€œSan Francisco Ballet at 90â€ on display, pre-security, in the International Terminal and online at: https://bit.ly/SFBalletAt90
